title: Sir Patrick Stewart supports assisted dying after friend’s ‘traumatic’ death
text:
Patrick Stewart appeared on This Morning (Picture: ITV)

Sir Patrick Stewart has opened up about how his decision to support an assisted dying campaign stemmed from the ‘traumatic’ death of his friend.

The 79-year-old actor is a campaigner for Dignity For Dying, an organisation campaigning to change the laws surrounding assisted dying for terminally ill citizens, which is illegal in the UK.

Speaking on This Morning to hosts Holly Willoughby and Phillip Schofield, Patrick recalled how the death of a friend’s wife motivated him to become more active on the matter.

‘A path that people could take when they were terminally ill and suffering has always seemed to me to be a sensible thing,’ Patrick said.

‘But then a friend of mine whose wife had been seriously ill with cancer and was in grave discomfort one night took an overdose which wasn’t sufficient – and she was taken to hospital and recovered from it.’

Patrick explained how when she returned home, she convinced her husband to take their dog out for a walk, and took her own life while he was out the house.

Patrick Stewart spoke about the organisation on This Morning (Picture: ITV)

‘[It was] a traumatic, painful, miserable way to die,’ Patrick said. ‘And a traumatic way for your husband to discover that’s the way you’ve died.

‘So often when I’m talking about doctor assisted dying it is the situation concerning loved ones, relatives, children, friends, like my friend telling me, where this comfort needs to be given.’

Patrick also revealed how his own heart disease diagnosis in 2011 was a ‘wake-up call’ to take more action on the subject.

Asked if it made him think about it more, Patrick said: ‘Well yes very much so. I was diagnosed very unexpectedly during my annual physical and my cardiologist said, “what are you doing this afternoon?” And I said well actually I’m going to Panama Pictures for lunch, and he said, “I’d rather you didn’t”.

‘And in five minutes I was on a gurney giving details of next of kin so it was rather dramatic. So I didn’t have time to brood on it, but all I knew was I was in the best possible hands there could have been and I was going to be taken care of. But yes it was a wake-up call.’
